gpt-message.content: You are an expert in hardware design with a deep understanding of Verilog RTL codes. Now I want to train a large language model for code comment generation tasks specifically focused on Verilog RTL codes. And I want you to help me process the raw data, transforming it into suitable formats that can serve as inputs and outputs for the model.

Name of the module and its functionality is as follows: 
Module name: generic_iobuf. 
Explanation: This is a simple generic Input Output Buffer (IOBUF) module without any specific inline comments. It has one output (O), one inout (IO), and two inputs (I and T). Key functionality includes: 

1. Assigning the state of IO to output O.
2. The IO port acts based on the control signal T and input I. If T is High, IO is high impedance (i.e., it doesn't drive anything). If T is Low, IO follows the state of input I.

Input and output ports and their explanation is as follows: 
Input ports: [I, T]. 
Explanation: 
1) I (data input): This port is used to feed the data into the module. When the T control signal is 'low', the state of this input port I will define the state of the inout port IO.
2) T (tri-state control): This port is used to determine whether the inout port IO is actively driving a logic level or not. If T is 'high', IO port will be at high impedance state (1'bz). 

Output ports: [O]. 
Explanation: 
1) O (data output): This port is used for output purposes. It's always showing the current state of inout port IO.

Inout ports: [IO].
Explanation:
1) IO (inout port): This port can function as an input or output, depending on the status of the input port T. It's connected to the outside world and reflects its status to the O port.

Internal signals and their explanation is as follows: 
The module doesn't use any internal signals. An internal signal, often a wire or a reg, would be defined and used within the module to perform some operations or hold some states. In this basic IOBUF module, the logic is directly carried out using the inputs and the inout outputs without any additional signal definitions. Therefore, there are no internal signals in this module.

Now I want to train a large language model for code comment generation tasks specifically focused on Verilog RTL codes. And I want you to help me process the raw data, transforming it into suitable formats that can serve as inputs and outputs for the model.

Name of the module and its functionality is as follows: 
Module name: generic_iobuf. 
Explanation: This is a simple generic Input Output Buffer (IOBUF) module without any specific inline comments. It has one output (O), one inout (IO), and two inputs (I and T). Key functionality includes: 

1. Assigning the state of IO to output O.
2. The IO port acts based on the control signal T and input I. If T is High, IO is high impedance (i.e., it doesn't drive anything). If T is Low, IO follows the state of input I.

Input and output ports and their explanation is as follows: 
Input ports: [I, T]. 
Explanation: 
1) I (data input): This port is used to feed the data into the module. When the T control signal is 'low', the state of this input port I will define the state of the inout port IO.
2) T (tri-state control): This port is used to determine whether the inout port IO is actively driving a logic level or not. If T is 'high', IO port will be at high impedance state (1'bz). 

Output ports: [O]. 
Explanation: 
1) O (data output): This port is used for output purposes. It's always showing the current state of inout port IO.

Inout ports: [IO].
Explanation:
1) IO (inout port): This port can function as an input or output, depending on the status of the input port T. It's connected to the outside world and reflects its status to the O port.

The module doesn't use any internal signals. An internal signal, often a wire or a reg, would be defined and used within the module to perform some operations or hold some states. In this basic IOBUF module, the logic is directly carried out using the inputs and the inout outputs without any additional signal definitions.
